member.name: T:SharpHook.BasicGlobalHookBase
member.summary: Represents an abstract implementation of which defines everything needed except for a strategy for handling events and uses a global hook provider (libuiohook by default).

member.name: M:SharpHook.BasicGlobalHookBase.#ctor(SharpHook.Data.GlobalHookType,SharpHook.Providers.IGlobalHookProvider,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of .
member.param: The underlying global hook provider, or to use the default one.
if should run the hook on a background thread. Otherwise, .

member.name: M:SharpHook.BasicGlobalHookBase.Finalize
member.summary: Stops the global hook if it's running.

member.name: P:SharpHook.BasicGlobalHookBase.IsRunning
member.summary: Gets the value which indicates whether the global hook is running.
member.value: if the global hook is running. Otherwise, .

member.name: P:SharpHook.BasicGlobalHookBase.IsDisposed
member.summary: Gets the value which indicates whether the global hook has been disposed.
member.value: if the global hook has been disposed. Otherwise, .
member.remarks: A disposed global hook cannot be started again.

member.name: M:SharpHook.BasicGlobalHookBase.Run
member.summary: Runs the global hook on the current thread, blocking it. The hook can be stopped temporarily by calling the method or stopped permanently by calling the method.
member.exception: Starting the global hook has failed.
The global hook is already running.
The global hook has been disposed.

member.name: M:SharpHook.BasicGlobalHookBase.RunAsync
member.summary: Runs the global hook without blocking the current thread. The hook can be stopped temporarily by calling the method or stopped permanently by calling the method.
member.returns: A which finishes when the hook is stopped or disposed.
member.exception: Starting the global hook has failed.
The global hook is already running.
The global hook has been disposed.
member.remarks: The hook is started on a separate thread.

member.name: M:SharpHook.BasicGlobalHookBase.Stop
member.summary: Stops the global hook.
member.exception: The global hook has been disposed.
member.remarks: After stopping, the global hook can run again.

member.name: M:SharpHook.BasicGlobalHookBase.Dispose
member.summary: Disposes of the global hook, stopping it if it is running.
member.remarks: After calling this method, the hook cannot run again. If you want to stop the global hook with the ability to run it again, call the method instead.

member.name: M:SharpHook.BasicGlobalHookBase.HandleHookEvent(SharpHook.Data.UioHookEvent@)
member.summary: When implemented in a derived class, represents a strategy for handling a hook event.

member.name: M:SharpHook.BasicGlobalHookBase.BeforeRun
member.summary: Defines actions to be done before the global hook is started. The default implementation does nothing, but it may change in a future version, so calling in an overriden method is recommended.

member.name: M:SharpHook.BasicGlobalHookBase.AfterStop
member.summary: Defines actions to be done after the global hook is stopped. The default implementation does nothing, but it may change in a future version, so calling in an overriden method is recommended.

member.name: M:SharpHook.BasicGlobalHookBase.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Disposes of the global hook, stopping it if it is running. This method will not be called if the global hook is already disposed.
member.param: if the method is called from the method. Otherwise, .

member.name: M:SharpHook.BasicGlobalHookBase.ThrowIfDisposed(System.String)
member.summary: Throws an if this object is disposed.
member.param: The method which calls this method.

member.name: T:SharpHook.Data.EventType
member.summary: Represents the type of an input event which can be raised from a global hook or posted as a fake event.

member.name: F:SharpHook.Data.EventType.HookEnabled
member.summary: Raised when the global hook is started. Ignored when posted.

member.name: F:SharpHook.Data.EventType.HookDisabled
member.summary: Raised when the global hook is stopped. Ignored when posted.

member.name: F:SharpHook.Data.EventType.KeyTyped
member.summary: Raised when a key press may have caused a character to be typed regardless of whether a character was actually typed. Ignored when posted.

remarks.para: Events of this type are raised after events of type if the pressed key may have caused characters to be typed regardless of whether they were actually typed. Since a single key press can cause multiple characters to be typed, a single event of type can cause multiple events of type .
Since events of this type are not raised by the OS, suppressing them has no effect.

member.name: F:SharpHook.Data.EventType.KeyPressed
member.summary: Raised when a key is pressed (its state changed from up to down) or posted to press a key.

member.name: F:SharpHook.Data.EventType.KeyReleased
member.summary: Raised when a key is released (its state changed from down to up) or posted to release a key.

member.name: F:SharpHook.Data.EventType.MouseClicked
member.summary: Raised when a mouse button is clicked. Ignored when posted.

remarks.para: Events of this type are raised after events of type if the mouse was not dragged.
Since events of this type are not raised by the OS, suppressing them has no effect.

member.name: F:SharpHook.Data.EventType.MousePressed
member.summary: Raised when a mouse button is pressed (its state changed from up to down) or posted to press a mouse button.

member.name: F:SharpHook.Data.EventType.MouseReleased
member.summary: Raised when a mouse button is released (its state changed from down to up) or posted to release a mouse button.

member.name: F:SharpHook.Data.EventType.MouseMoved
member.summary: Raised when the mouse is moved or posted to move the mouse.

member.name: F:SharpHook.Data.EventType.MouseDragged
member.summary: Raised when the mouse is dragged. Not recommended to post as it will be the same as .

member.name: F:SharpHook.Data.EventType.MouseWheel
member.summary: Raised when the mouse wheel is scrolled or posted to scroll the mouse wheel.

member.name: F:SharpHook.Data.EventType.MousePressedIgnoreCoordinates
member.summary: Posted to press a mouse button at the current coordinates. Never raised.

member.name: F:SharpHook.Data.EventType.MouseReleasedIgnoreCoordinates
member.summary: Posted to release a mouse button at the current coordinates. Never raised.

member.name: F:SharpHook.Data.EventType.MouseMovedRelativeToCursor
member.summary: Posted to move the mouse relative to the current cursor position. Never raised.

member.name: T:SharpHook.EventLoopGlobalHook
member.summary: Represents an implementation of which dispatches events to an event loop running on a separate dedicated thread.

remarks.para: The event handlers will run on a separate thread. This way the hook itself will not be blocked if the handlers are long-running. The exception is the event which will run on the same thread on which the hook itself is running since at that point it doesn't matter anymore that the hook is not blocked.
Setting inside the handlers will have no effect as they are run on another thread.

member.name: P:SharpHook.EventSimulator.TextSimulationDelayOnX11
member.summary: Gets or sets the delay between simulating individual characters when simulating text on Linux.
member.value: The delay between simulating individual characters when simulating text on Linux.

remarks.para: X11 doesn't support simulating arbitrary Unicode characters directly. Instead, for each character, an unused key code is remapped to that character, and then key press/release is simulated. Since the receiving application must react to the remapping, and may not do so instantaneously, a delay is needed for accurate simulation.
The default delay is 50 milliseconds.
On Windows and macOS this property is ignored.

member.name: M:SharpHook.EventSimulator.SimulateKeyPress(SharpHook.Data.KeyCode)
member.summary: Simulates pressing a key.
member.param: The code of the key to press.

member.name: M:SharpHook.EventSimulator.SimulateKeyRelease(SharpHook.Data.KeyCode)
member.summary: Simulates releasing a key.
member.param: The code of the key to release.

member.name: M:SharpHook.EventSimulator.SimulateTextEntry(System.String)
member.summary: Simulates the input of arbitrary Unicode characters.

remarks.para: The text to simulate doesn't depend on the current keyboard layout. The full range of UTF-16 (including surrogate pairs, e.g. emojis) is supported.
On Windows text simulation should work correctly and consistently.
On macOS applications are not required to process text simulation, but most of them should handle it correctly.

X11 doesn't support text simulation directly. Instead, for each character, an unused key code is remapped to that character, and then key press/release is simulated. Since the receiving application must react to the remapping, and may not do so instantaneously, a delay is needed for accurate simulation. This means that text simulation on Linux works slowly and is not guaranteed to be correct. can be used to increase (or decrease) the delay if needed – longer delays add consistency but may be more jarring to end users. can also be used to get the currently configured delay – the default is 50 milliseconds.

member.name: M:SharpHook.EventSimulator.SimulateMouseWheel(System.Int16,SharpHook.Data.MouseWheelScrollDirection,SharpHook.Data.MouseWheelScrollType)
member.summary: Simulates scrolling the mouse wheel.
member.param: The wheel rotation. A positive value indicates that the wheel will be rotated up or left, and a negative value indicates that the wheel will be rotated down or right.
The scroll type (considered only on macOS).

remarks.para: On Windows the value 120 represents the default wheel step. As such, multiples of 120 can be used, but it's not required. The value of is ignored.
On macOS it's recommended to use values between -10 and 10. This will result in quite a small scroll amount with pixel scrolling, so is recommended for line scrolling instead of pixel scrolling.
On Linux there is no fixed recommendation, but multiples of 100 can be used. The value of is ignored.

member.name: T:SharpHook.IEventSimulator
member.summary: Represents an object which can simulate keyboard and mouse events.
member.remarks: The methods of this interface correspond to constants defined in the enum.

member.name: P:SharpHook.IEventSimulator.TextSimulationDelayOnX11
member.summary: Gets or sets the delay between simulating individual characters when simulating text on Linux.
member.value: The delay between simulating individual characters when simulating text on Linux.

remarks.para: X11 doesn't support simulating arbitrary Unicode characters directly. Instead, for each character, an unused key code is remapped to that character, and then key press/release is simulated. Since the receiving application must react to the remapping, and may not do so instantaneously, a delay is needed for accurate simulation.
The default delay is 50 milliseconds.
On Windows and macOS this property is ignored.

member.name: M:SharpHook.IEventSimulator.SimulateTextEntry(System.String)
member.summary: Simulates the input of arbitrary Unicode characters.

remarks.para: The text to simulate doesn't depend on the current keyboard layout. The full range of UTF-16 (including surrogate pairs, e.g. emojis) is supported.
On Windows text simulation should work correctly and consistently.
On macOS applications are not required to process text simulation, but most of them should handle it correctly.

X11 doesn't support text simulation directly. Instead, for each character, an unused key code is remapped to that character, and then key press/release is simulated. Since the receiving application must react to the remapping, and may not do so instantaneously, a delay is needed for accurate simulation. This means that text simulation on Linux works slowly and is not guaranteed to be correct. can be used to increase (or decrease) the delay if needed – longer delays add consistency but may be more jarring to end users. can also be used to get the currently configured delay – the default is 50 milliseconds.

member.summary: Simulates scrolling the mouse wheel.
member.param: The wheel rotation. A positive value indicates that the wheel will be rotated up or left, and a negative value indicates that the wheel will be rotated down or right.
The scroll type (considered only on macOS).

remarks.para: On Windows the value 120 represents the default wheel step. As such, multiples of 120 can be used, but it's not required. The value of is ignored.
On macOS it's recommended to use values between -10 and 10. This will result in quite a small scroll amount with pixel scrolling, so is recommended for line scrolling instead of pixel scrolling.
On Linux there is no fixed recommendation, but multiples of 100 can be used. The value of is ignored.

member.name: T:SharpHook.Logging.LogEntry
member.summary: Represents a log entry from libuiohook.
member.param: The full text of the log entry.
The format of the log entry which can be used in String.Format.
The native format of the log entry.
The arguments of the log entry which can be used in String.Format.
The arguments as they appear in the entry's full text.
The argument placeholders from the native format.

remarks.para: For simple handling the and properties are anough. For more advanced handling you can use the entries' formats and arguments.

Each log entry from libuiohook has the following format:
function [line]: message

The function and line reference the source code of libuiohook itself, and can be retrieved using the and properties. The message can be retrieved by splitting the text by : and getting the trimmed second part.
You shouldn't create instances yourself. Instead, use the class to create them in the logging callback.

member.name: M:SharpHook.Native.UioHook.RunKeyboard
member.summary: Runs the global hook only for keyboard events and blocks the thread until it's stopped.

remarks.para: This method makes a difference only on Windows where there are two different global hooks – a keyboard hook and a mouse hook. On macOS and Linux there is one hook for all events, and this method simply enables filtering mouse events out on these OSes.
When a keyboard-only hook is running, the field will not contain any mouse button state.
This method must not be called when a global hook is already running since it will corrupt the global state of libuiohook.

member.name: M:SharpHook.Native.UioHook.RunMouse
member.summary: Runs the global hook only for mouse events and blocks the thread until it's stopped.

remarks.para: This method makes a difference only on Windows where there are two different global hooks – a keyboard hook and a mouse hook. On macOS and Linux there is one hook for all events, and this method simply enables filtering keyboard events out on these OSes.
When a mouse-only hook is running, the field will not contain any keyboard modifier state.
This method must not be called when a global hook is already running since it will corrupt the global state of libuiohook.

member.summary: Simulates the input of arbitrary Unicode characters.

remarks.para: The text to simulate doesn't depend on the current keyboard layout. The full range of UTF-16 (including surrogate pairs, e.g., emojis) is supported.
On Windows, text simulation should work correctly and consistently.
On macOS, applications are not required to process text simulation, but most of them should handle it correctly.

X11 doesn't support text simulation directly. Instead, for each character, an unused key code is remapped to that character, and then key press/release is simulated. Since the receiving application must react to the remapping, and may not do so instantaneously, a delay is needed for accurate simulation. This means that text simulation on Linux works slowly and is not guaranteed to be correct. can be used to increase (or decrease) the delay if needed – longer dealys add consistency but may be more jarring to end users. can be used to get the currently configured delay – the default is 50 milliseconds.

remarks.para: X11 doesn't support posting arbitrary Unicode characters directly. Instead, for each character, an unused key code is remapped to that character, and then key press/release is simulated. Since the receiving application must react to the remapping, and may not do so instantaneously, a delay is needed for accurate simulation.
The default delay is 50 milliseconds.
On Windows and macOS, this method always returns 0.

member.name: T:SharpHook.Providers.IEventSimulationProvider
member.summary: Represents a provider of low-level event simulation functionality.

member.name: P:SharpHook.Providers.IEventSimulationProvider.PostTextDelayX11
member.summary: Gets or sets the delay (in nanoseconds) between posting individual characters when posting text on Linux.
member.value: The delay (in nanoseconds) between posting individual characters when posting text on Linux.

remarks.para: X11 doesn't support posting arbitrary Unicode characters directly. Instead, for each character, an unused key code is remapped to that character, and then key press/release is simulated. Since the receiving application must react to the remapping, and may not do so instantaneously, a delay is needed for accurate simulation.
The default delay is 50 milliseconds.
On Windows and macOS, this property does nothing and always returns 0.

member.name: M:SharpHook.Providers.IEventSimulationProvider.PostText(System.String)
member.summary: Simulates the input of arbitrary Unicode characters.

remarks.para: The text to simulate doesn't depend on the current keyboard layout. The full range of UTF-16 (including surrogate pairs, e.g., emojis) is supported.
On Windows, text simulation should work correctly and consistently.
On macOS, applications are not required to process text simulation, but most of them should handle it correctly.

X11 doesn't support text simulation directly. Instead, for each character, an unused key code is remapped to that character, and then key press/release is simulated. Since the receiving application must react to the remapping, and may not do so instantaneously, a delay is needed for accurate simulation. This means that text entry on Linux works slowly and is not guaranteed to be correct. can be used to get or set the delay if needed – longer delays add consistency but may be more jarring to end users – the default is 50 milliseconds.

member.remarks: The event handlers should generally be fast and simple so that the thread can process all raised events. If you need to do a lot of processing in the event handlers then consider using another implementation, e.g., .

member.name: T:SharpHook.TaskPoolGlobalHook
member.summary: Represents a task pool-based implementation of .

remarks.para: The event handlers will run with the specified parallelism level on separate threads inside the default thread pool for tasks. This way the hook itself will not be blocked if the handlers are long-running. The exception is the event which will run on the same thread on which the hook itself is running since at that point it doesn't matter anymore that the hook is not blocked.
Setting inside the handlers will have no effect as they are run on other threads.

member.name: M:SharpHook.Testing.TestProvider.Run
member.summary: Runs the testing hook if is set to . Otherwise, does nothing.
member.remarks: Depending on the threading mode, this method will either run an event loop or do nothing and wait for the hook to be stopped.

member.name: M:SharpHook.Testing.TestProvider.PostEvent(SharpHook.Data.UioHookEvent@)
member.summary: Posts an input event if is set to - this event will be dispatched if the provider is running. Otherwise, does nothing.
member.remarks: If the provider's threading mode is then this method will immediately dispatch the event. If the threading mode is then the event will be posted to an event loop which runs on the same thread on which the testing hook itself runs, and then dispatched there.

member.name: M:SharpHook.Testing.TestProvider.IsAxApiEnabled(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Checks whether access to macOS Accessibility API is enabled for the process.
member.returns: if at least one of , , or is configured to return . Otherwise, .
member.remarks: In general, if the test provider should simulate the macOS Accessibility API being disabled, then all three properties – , , and – should be configured to return , for consistency with real Accessibility API checks.

member.name: T:SharpHook.Testing.TestThreadingMode
member.summary: Represents the mode of dispatching simulated events in testing hooks – either on the same thread which simulates them, or on the thread which runs the testing hook.

member.name: F:SharpHook.Testing.TestThreadingMode.Simple
member.summary: Simulated events will be dispatched immediately on the same thread which simulates them.

member.name: F:SharpHook.Testing.TestThreadingMode.EventLoop
member.summary: Simulated events will be posted to an event loop and dispatched on the thread on which the testing hook runs.
